review_title: We’ll never allow work from home
job_title: RSC Representative III in Tampa, FL
pros: Free internet They pay for lunch once a month sometimes
cons: We can do everything from home but the company is stuck in the past and thinks people cannot handle not being forced to work in a smelly office where you can barely ever find parking. Regardless of how well your stats are, working from home will never be an option. Just here until I can find a better work from home position.

There were many positives at the company but the constant chaos made them hard to identify/experience as an employee.

job_title: Inbound Residential Sales in West Columbia, SC

cons: Higher ups lie to you during training and once you’re in the floor. You end up lying to customers about cable and mobile services and have no idea. They don’t support you as an employee. HR takes nothing seriously. And if you have any kind of disability, good luck. They claim they are big on mental health but literally bullied me for having mental illnesses and for having a hard time at work. The call floor is incredibly loud and you can’t hear your customers half the time from music or tv or people yelling. Everyone there is lying about something. It’s like high school drama but worse.

pros: Great pay, and benefits. They take care of their employees.
cons: They have horrible business practices such as forcing you to make a customer keep services that were added to their account. Not providing customers they due credit or refund if they don't ask for it. They say they are transparent, but non of the promotions customer receive include the cost if hidden fees. They constantly raise their prices making the retention job a lot harder than it should be. Team leads are constantly micro-managing since your work is a big chunk of their bonus. Very hard to get promoted if you have a disability that requires you to take time off since you cannot miss work to get a promotion.

pros: Almost everyone is doing the same thing you are so everyone is helpful and is understanding. The training is 12 weeks so you feel like you are ready by time they put you into production. The employees are great. The benefits are great.
cons: They are very very very strict with your schedule. Throughout the day every minute is monitored to make sure you are 100% working. The customers can be really nasty. Saying the job is repetitive is an understatement.

review_title: If pregnant do not apply they don't care

They told me they could only excuse me if I tested positive for covid.

job_title: Advanced Video Engineer IV in Greenwood Village, CO
pros:
The pay is a plus
If you put in the time and play your cards right, you will be compensated well
Co-workers are great
Direct leadership team is great and understanding
The job its self is very straightforward, teams are well organized and work pretty well together
cons:
The biggest con is that we are forced to show up to an office to do a job that is 100% remote. There is no reason for anyone in video operations to be in the same physical building, yet management continues to insist that we show up at least three days a week. None of the equipment I work on is located in the building that I work in. I have meetings scheduled a few times a week, and even if I am in the same building as the other folks in the meeting, it is hosted remotely. Management is not transparent at all regarding why we are still in the office, and HR refuses to allow someone with COVID to work remotely. Instead forcing them to use their PTO.

Politics can play too large of a role in whether or not you are promoted.

Logic is sometimes thrown out the window when making decisions around how to build things for the future. Rather than work on building out the next gen architecture, we continue to band-aid existing builds. 

Timelines for getting things done are slow
The same tasks do not take the same priority amongst different verticals causing projects to take far longer to complete then they should

review_title: Company Culture Fabulous! Leaders within IT need training.
job_title: IT Project Manager in Charlotte, NC
pros: The Company itself is great! To say that I love the Brand and culture would be an understatement. Great benefits and salaries. Chris Winfrey is the best! A real leader. Hoping he can implement the change the org so badly needs, or get a leader who can do it for those who are left.
cons: IT is IT. Hasn't changed in 20+ years. Don't expect too much from IT leadership, who are soured on lack of promos and recognition. Minimal diversity. No one on ones. Turnover is the only escape. Sadly it hasn't changed with the times, and IT leaders don't seem to notice.

pros: The bonus, My coworkers,Pay rate, and Teamwork Training

review_title: I love what I do but not the company

COL in this area is crazy high even before pandemic. So we never get ahead. I struggle more now then early in my career. Bonuses are descent but it just helps me pay my bills once a year. If I didn’t love the work I definitely would look to get out.

job_title: Customer Support Specialist I in Eatonville, FL
pros: Ok, pay rate. Food trucks are on-site weekly.
cons: One of the largest Internet Service Providers (ISPs) of whom customer's issues never seem to get fixed. Spectrum TV Application always has an outage. In a world where the internet connection in a household is no longer a luxury and is now a necessity, the internet should be readily available. Customers call into tears daily with no relief as Charter Communications (Spectrum) is the only ISP in their location or region. The training curriculum should be more hands-on to prepare new employees on how to resolve issues that can be resolved. There is no flexibility in schedule preferences. You are given a schedule and stuck with the said schedule for one year. No flexibility to work from home, with the cost of gas prices rising every day. Low momentum & spirit in the call center environment. No assigned seating.

review_title: A refreshing approach to storytelling, with great benefits
pros: I appreciate the network style to focus on characters and context, to make a lasting impact on viewers rather than stories they’ll forget about in 15 minutes. More experienced producers have a good amount of freedom to shape the stories in their newscasts and help dictate coverage. The company benefits are some of the best in the business, with free cable to boot!
cons: Company culture is strong but can use improvement to improve morale and encourage growth among new employees. There needs to be more of a focus on improving training to teach proper news gathering. Managers should devote more time to correcting small mistakes before they snowball into larger ones.

review_title: Job Satisfaction Depends On Business Unit
pros: Charter pays their employees well. The company is also incredibly well organized and employees very talented people in senior leadership. They're very careful in their decision-making, as leadership has executed successfully on their playbook for years. Much of employee satisfaction is dependent on Business Unit. Therefore, opinions will widely vary from one person/department to another.
cons: Most senior leadership and ascending talent is located in Stamford, Connecticut... as are nearly all the opportunities for any significant advancement. Stamford is an ungodly expensive in terms of cost of living (also not the best weather). Charter is big on compliance to their playbook and siloed operations... which is both a strength and weakness in my opinion. So long as they can continue to employ people who will comply (and are handsomely compensated in doing so), they'll surely continue to succeed. However, as the market evolves to more employee friendly environments, Charter may lose talent to other opportunities. Only a select few Business Units allow remote work. It's not a place to go if you're looking for flexibility or a modern work arrangement.

review_title: Loved the job, but business rules hinder growth.
pros: If you love helping your coworkers this is exactly the job you want. Trouble shooting, performing inventory testing new hardware, upgrading existing hardware. This was more of a hobby so it was fun.
cons:
The issue was when a company grows rapidly, there's a lot of extra work including your regular duties and in my case management never understood the scope of work nor did they know/care about what they were asking for. Whether it a 10 minute request or something that took time and planning. So huge tasks were requested with little to n
No notice and would complain when we pushed back that we did not have enough time to complete.

review_title: Very boring, gave me no work.
job_title: Junior Platform Engineer in Denver, CO
pros:
- People are cool.
- Work life balance.
- If you just want a paycheck and dont care about your future career, if you just want to show up to work and absorb money, then this is your place.
cons:
- Ancient tech (little cloud usage, they want to utilize their own old data centers).
- Ultra disorganized.
- Nothing to do.
- Sexist towards men
- Really cringe "happy birthday to you" singing events
- Terrible if you want to kick off your career or prove yourself.
They favor women 100%. All the opportunities go to women, they get promotions, and women don't need a Comp Sci degree to get an interview (but required for men). 

-For the 1 year I worked there I didnt do anything, it's a clown show. I probably said for 30 days total "I have nothing to do" and they didnt assign me anything. I found something to do so that it makes it seem like I'm useful and trying. Sometimes they gave me busy work but no one looked over my work and no one used my work. I have no idea why they hired me.

review_title: Large Account Sales Leadership needs help
pros: Large company with a wide variety of work groups. Good benefits.
cons: Residential and SMB groups are what they are. Its a cable company so not a lot of variety of services to cause confusion in sales. Large account sales is another story. Frontline employees have no credibility and senior leadership leads by fear. As other reviewers have stated. Comply and be silent or move out.

review_title: A wonderful friendly environment, with a struggling corporate culture.
pros: Great relationships, everything at the local level has been a great experience.
cons: Working in Technology has been a frustrating experience. The company as a whole has a culture of 'If it costs money, don't spend it.' We have PCs on a 7 year life cycle, getting new equipment is like pulling teeth, our agents have metrics that are struggling and impacted by this faulty equipment. I've never felt more set up for failure in a role than this one. Charter's technology footprint needs to evolve and catch up with the expectations, demand, and needs for the modern era. Which is a paradox, because Charter is a telecommunications company who makes their money in technology.

job_title: Sales Account Executive in Worcester, MA
pros: Benefits - 401k match, free cable
cons: Poor management since Time Warner took over. They hired people to get rid of the long time former Charter Communications employees. Heavily micromanaged. Tell you to sell whatever you can with unobtainable quotas and then they will question it and take sales away from you. Zero account protection. You find a sale and another rep enters an order and you lost it. Usually a coworker that will take it. Its a backstabbing environment. No work life balance. Oh, and HR don't even think they help the "employee." They are corrupt and for the employer only. They will never help you even when management is harassing you, which is very common there as well. I was the only female in the sales department and they treated me like garbage. Manager had closed door meetings constantly with me and no other person present. Screamed at me for no reason but never did that to the male employees. I complained because the work environment was so bad and they terminated me after 20 years). The manager I complained about (who was only there a year), was fired about 5 months later. Look elsewhere unless you want free cable for a while and you like torture. Or do like the majority of the sales people I worked with did. Work there for 6 months, take your ramp pay while you look for a better job or have them fire you so you can just collect and keep looking for a better job. Amazing how they never caught on yet they let the seasoned, dedicated employees go.

cons: Outdated culture, few local promotional opportunities.

review_title: Simultaneously the best and worst job I have ever worked
pros:
- Company is mismanaged, you can basically do whatever you want
- People are very nice
- Pay can be negotiated to obscenely high amounts
- Not a high-pressure environment at all
cons:
- Company is mismanaged to a massive degree and operates worse than the government
- Work is really boring and not fulfilling
- Employees are fine being mediocre and don't have the passion that some tech workers have
- Pervasive laziness from many on-site employees, while the off-site employees work non-stop
- Jira boards routinely have 3-4 year old tickets on them (in your current sprint)
- Since the company makes money regardless of whether or not the product is good, there is no incentive to make a good product
- BASICALLY NO CODING at a software engineering job
- aws instances are slow despite this company bringing in mountains of cash
- Many senior developers did not know how the product fit together
- NONEXISTENT DOCUMENTATION for all facets of the product. Have fun combing through 40,000+ plus lines of code for a small bug
- Due to the way the software is managed, bugs that get fixed on one platform might still exist on other platforms for months
- None of the work actually matters, You will likely be fixing meaningless small software bugs that 99.9999999% of client's wont use
- Charter hiring team has no issue branding test/verification jobs as developer jobs
- Senior devs think they're really cool despite not programming once in the last 6-7 years
- Meetings are meaningless and usually very long. Oftentimes you will just see senior devs squabbling over small features that don't matter to the overall use of the product
- The back end for the charter internet provisioning system is ancient, maybe 2-3 people in the entire company knows how it works and no one ever bothered to tell the new workers how to use it/update it so it's easier to use
- Company relies on bad third-party management software for most of its systems and the system is often down
- layers and layers and layers of upper management just get in the way of a good product/internet experience
- Sometimes fellow engineers get a call from their wife and leave the office for 2 hours every day for god knows what reason (when they are working on the same task as you)
- test team is useless and oftentimes the workflow is just: test team tests bug -> can't find the bug -> assigns to dev team -> dev team confirms issue exists-> assign back to testers -> they can't see an issue that exists on our setup that took 5 minutes to test.
- None of the above issues will be fixed because charter does not care to fix them.
